sen.j: 唐招提寺（とうしょうだいじ）は、奈良市五条町にある鑑真ゆかりの寺院。
sen.e: Toshodai-ji Temple, located in Gojo-cho, Nara city, Toshodai-ji Temple, is noted in connection with Jianzhen.
Toshodai-ji Temple, located in Gojo-cho, Nara city, Toshodai-ji Temple, is noted in connection with Jianzhen.
Toshodai-ji Temple, located in Gojo-cho, Nara city, is noted in connection with Jianzhen.
sen.cmt: 重複する語を削除しました。

sen.j: 南都六宗の一つである律宗の総本山である。
sen.e: It is Sohonzan (the head temple of a Buddhist sect) of the Ritsu sect, one of the Nanto rokushu (the six sects of Buddhism which flourished in ancient Nara).
It is the sohonzan (the head temple of a Buddhist sect) of the Ritsu sect, one of the nanto rokushu (the six sects of Buddhism which flourished in ancient Nara).
It is the sohonzan (the head temple of a Buddhist sect) of the Ritsu sect, one of the nanto rokushu (the six sects of Buddhism which flourished in ancient Nara).

sen.j: 本尊は毘盧遮那仏、開基（創立者）は鑑真である。
sen.e: Its honzon (principal image of Buddha) is Vairocana, and its Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding)is Jianzhen.
Its honzon (principal image of Buddha) is Vairocana, and its kaiki (patron of a temple at the time of its founding) is Jianzhen.
Its honzon (principal image of Buddha) is Vairocana, and its kaiki (patron of a temple at the time of its founding) is Jianzhen.

sen.j: 井上靖の小説『天平の甍』で広く知られるようになった中国・唐出身の僧鑑真が晩年を過ごした寺である。
sen.e: Jianzhen from Tong Dynasty in China--a monk who became widely known through a novel titled "Tempyo no Iraka" (the roof tile in the Tempyo period)" written by Yasushi INOUE--spent his late years in this temple..
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Jianzhen from Tong Dynasty China, a monk who became widely known through a novel entitled "Tempyo no Iraka" (Roof Tiles of the Tempyo Period) written by Yasushi INOUE, spent his later years in this temple..

Jianzhen from Tong Dynasty China, a monk who became widely known through a novel entitled "Tempyo no Iraka" (Roof Tiles of the Tempyo Period) written by Yasushi INOUE, spent his later years in this temple.
sen.cmt: 余分なピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: 奈良時代建立の金堂、講堂をはじめ、多くの文化財を有する。
sen.e: The temple has many cultural assets including its Kon-do Hall (main hall of a Buddhist temple) and Kodo Hall (lecture hall) founded in the Nara Period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The temple has many cultural assets including its Kon-do Hall (main hall) and Kodo Hall (lecture hall), both founded in the Nara Period.
sen.cmt: Unnecessary explanation removed, added for clarity.
sen.e: The temple has many cultural assets including its Kon-do Hall (main hall) and Kodo Hall (lecture hall), both founded in the Nara Period.

sen.j: 『続日本紀』等によれば、唐招提寺は唐僧・鑑真が天平宝字3年（759年）、新田部親王（にいたべしんのう、天武天皇第7皇子）の旧宅跡を朝廷から譲り受け、寺としたものである。
sen.e: "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued) and other descriptions say that Jianzhen, a priest of Tang, was granted a former residence of Imperial Prince Niitabe (the 7th prince of Emperor Tenmu) by the Imperial Court in 759 to make it a temple.

"Shoku Nihongi" (The Chronicles of Japan Continued) and other sources say that Jianzhen, a priest, was granted a former residence of Imperial Prince Niitabe (the 7th prince of Emperor Tenmu) by the Imperial Court in 759 to make it into a temple.

"Shoku Nihongi" (The Chronicles of Japan Continued) and other sources say that Jianzhen, a priest, was granted a former residence of Imperial Prince Niitabe (the 7th prince of Emperor Tenmu) by the Imperial Court in 759 to make it into a temple.

sen.j: 寺名の「招提」は、サンスクリット由来の中国語で、元来は「四方」「広い」などの意味を表わす語であった。
sen.e: "Tosho" contained in the temple name is a Chinese word from Sanskrit which means "four corners," "wide," and so on.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The "tosho" contained in the temple name is a Chinese word originally from Sanskrit which means "four corners" and "wide".
sen.cmt: Grammar, added for clarity, punctuation, style.
sen.e: The "shodai" contained in the temple name is a Chinese word originally from Sanskrit which means "four corners" and "wide."
sen.cmt: tosho→shodai, ピリオドの位置を修正しました。

sen.j: 「寺」「院」「精舎」「蘭若」などと同様、仏教寺院（私寺）を指す一般名詞として使われていた。
sen.e: Like words such as "Tera " "In" "Shoja" and "Rannya" the word "Tosho" was used as a general noun to identify Buddhist temples (including private temples).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Like words such as "tera ", "in", "shoja" and "rannya", the word "tosho" was used as a general noun to identify Buddhist temples (including private temples).
Like words such as "tera," "in," "shoja" and "ranny,a" the word "tosho" was used as a general noun to identify Buddhist temples (including private temples).
sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置を修正しました。

sen.j: つまり、本寺の寺名の由来としては、「唐僧である鑑真和上のための寺」というような意味合いであるとされている。
sen.e: That is to say that the origin of the temple name is said to have a meaning of "a temple for a priest of Tang--Jianzhen, Ganjin-wajo."
That is to say that the origin of the temple's name is said to derive from "a temple for the priest of Tang, Jianzhen, Ganjin-wajo".
That is to say that the origin of the temple's name is said to derive from "a temple for the priest of Tang, Jianzhen, Ganjin-wajo."
sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置を修正しました。

tit.j: 鑑真の渡日と戒律の伝来
tit.e: Jianzhen Visited Japan and introduced religious precepts
Jianzhen's visits to Japan and the introduction of religious precepts
Jianzhen's visits to Japan and the introduction of religious precepts

sen.j: 鑑真（688年 - 763年）の生涯については、日本に同行した弟子の思託が記した『大和上伝』、それをもとにした淡海三船（おうみのみふね）の『唐大和上東征伝』、井上靖の『天平の甍』などに詳しい。
sen.e: The life of Jianzhen (688 - 763) is described in details, for example, in "Daiwajoden" written by Shitaku, a disciple who accompanied Jianzhen, "Todaiwajo Toseiden (Eastern Expedition of the Great T'ang Monk)" written by OMI no Mifune based on "Daiwajoden," and "Tempyo no Iraka" by Yasushi INOUE.

The life of Jianzhen (688 - 763) is described in detail in "Daiwajoden" written by Shitaku, a disciple who accompanied Jianzhen, "Todaiwajo Toseiden (The Eastern Expedition of the Great T'ang Monk)" written by OMI no Mifune based on "Daiwajoden", and "Tempyo no Iraka" by Yasushi INOUE, among others.

The life of Jianzhen (688 - 763) is described in detail in "Daiwajoden" written by Shitaku, a disciple who accompanied Jianzhen, "Todaiwajo Toseiden (The Eastern Expedition of the Great T'ang Monk)" written by OMI no Mifune based on "Daiwajoden," and "Tempyo no Iraka" by Yasushi INOUE, among others.
sen.cmt: カンマの位置を修正しました。

sen.j: 鑑真は仏教者に戒律を授ける導師「伝戒の師」として日本に招請された。
sen.e: Jianzhen was invited to Japan as a teacher of Kairitus (the religious precepts of Buddhism) for instructing them for Buddhist followers.
Jianzhen was invited to Japan to be a teacher of kairitsu (the religious precepts of Buddhism) to Buddhist followers.
Jianzhen was invited to Japan to be a teacher of kairitsu (the religious precepts of Buddhism) to Buddhist followers.

sen.j: 「戒律」とは「規範」「きまり」といった意味で、仏教者が日常生活上守らなければならない事柄である。
sen.e: "Kairitsu" means something like "norm" and "rules," a set of things for the followers to follow in their daily life.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: "Kairitsu" means "norm" or "rules", a set of things for the followers to practise in their daily life.
"Kairitsu" means "norm" or "rules," a set of things for the followers to practice in their daily life.

sen.j: 一般の仏教信者に授ける「菩薩戒」と、正式の僧に授ける「具足戒」とがある。
sen.e: It consists of Bosatsu-kai (Bodhisattva Precepts) for general followers of Buddhism and "Gusokukai" for proper monks.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It consists of Bosatsu-kai (Bodhisattva Precepts) for general followers of Buddhism and "Gusokukai" for proper monks.
It consists of Bosatsu-kai (Bodhisattva Precepts) for general followers of Buddhism and "Gusokukai" for proper monks.

sen.j: 出家者が正式の僧となるためには、「戒壇」という施設で、有資格者の僧から「具足戒」を受けねばならない。
sen.e: A renunciant monk has to be taught "Gusokukai" by a qualified monk in a facility called "Kaidan" to become a proper monk.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: A renunciant monk had to be taught "Gusokukai" by a qualified monk in a facility called "Kaidan" in order to become a proper monk.
A renunciant monk had to be taught "Gusokukai" by a qualified monk in a facility called "Kaidan" in order to become a proper monk.

sen.j: 当時（8世紀前半）の日本には正式の戒壇はなく、戒律を授ける資格のある僧も不足していた。
sen.e: At that time (in the early eighth century) there was no officially established Kaidan in Japan and insufficient number of monks qualified to teach precepts.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: At that time (in the early eighth century) there was no officially established Kaidan in Japan and an insufficient number of monks were qualified to teach precepts.
At that time (in the early eighth century) there was no officially established Kaidan in Japan and an insufficient number of monks were qualified to teach precepts.

sen.j: 天平5年（733年）、遣唐使とともに渡唐した留学僧の普照と栄叡（ようえい）は、日本に正式の戒壇を設立するため、しかるべき導師を招請するよう、朝廷からの命を受けていた。
sen.e: Fusho and Yoei who went over to China with a Japanese envoy to Tang Dynasty China in 733 had been ordered by the Imperial Court to invite a suitably qualified person to Japan to establish an official Kairitsu in Japan.
Fusho and Yoei, who went with a Japanese envoy to Tang Dynasty China in 733, had been ordered by the Imperial Court to invite a suitably qualified person to Japan to establish an official kairitsu.
Fusho and Yoei, who went with a Japanese envoy to Tang Dynasty China in 733, had been ordered by the Imperial Court to invite a suitably qualified person to Japan to establish an official kairitsu.

sen.j: 彼らが揚州（現・江蘇省）の高僧鑑真に初めて会ったのは西暦742年のことであった。
sen.e: It was 742 that they met Jianzhen, a high rank monk in Yangzhou (present-day Jiangsu Province) for the first time.
They met Jianzhen, a high rank monk in Yangzhou (present-day Jiangsu Province) for the first time in 742.
They met Jianzhen, a high rank monk in Yangzhou (present-day Jiangsu Province) for the first time in 742.

sen.j: 鑑真は渡日を承諾するが、当時の航海は命がけであり、鑑真は足掛け12年の間に5回も渡航に失敗した。
sen.e: Jianzhen accepted their offer to visit Japan, but he failed in sailing to Japan--a life-threatening journey at that time--as may as 5 times over 12 years.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Jianzhen accepted their offer to visit Japan, but he failed to reach Japan by boat, a life-threatening journey at that time, as many as five times over twelve years.
Jianzhen accepted their offer to visit Japan, but he failed to reach Japan by boat, a life-threatening journey at that time, as many as five times over twelve years.

sen.j: 5回目の航海では中国最南端の海南島まで流され、それまで行動をともにしてきた栄叡を失い、自らは失明するという苦難を味わった。
sen.e: In his 5th attempt, he was flown to Hainan, the southernmost tip of China and encountered suffering that he lost Yoei who had been in company so far and his own eyesight.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: At his fifth attempt he was forced to sail to Hainan at the southernmost tip of China, and after losing Yoei who had accompanied him so far, he also suffered the burden of losing his eyesight.
At his fifth attempt he was forced to sail to Hainan at the southernmost tip of China, and after losing Yoei who had accompanied him so far, he also suffered the burden of losing his eyesight.

sen.j: 753年、6回目の渡航でようやく来日に成功する。
sen.e: In 753, in his 6th attempt, he was eventually successful in sailing to Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 753, on his 6th attempt, he was eventually successful in reaching Japan.
In 753, on his 6th attempt, he was eventually successful in reaching Japan.

sen.j: この時も国禁を犯し、日本の遣唐使船に便乗しての渡航であった。
sen.e: In this occasion, he also had to break a national ban for his journey and boarded Kentoshi Ship from Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: On this occasion, he also had to break a ban on entering the country for his journey on board a Kentoshi Ship from Japan.
On this occasion, he also had to break a ban on entering the country for his journey on board a Kentoshi Ship from Japan.

sen.j: 鑑真は当時すでに66歳になっていた。
sen.e: He was already 66 years old at that time.
He was already 66 years old at the time.
He was already 66 years old at the time.

sen.j: 天平勝宝5年（753年）12月、薩摩（琉球ともいう）に上陸した鑑真は、翌天平勝宝6年（754年）2月、ようやく難波津（大阪）に上陸た。
sen.e: After Jianzhen landed in Satsuma (although some suggest Ryukyu) in December, 753, he eventually landed in Naniwa no tsu (Naniwa Port) (Osaka) in February, 754., and taught Bosatsu-kai (Bodhisattva Precepts) for Emperor Shomu, Empress Komyo, Empress Koken, and so forth in front of Daibutsu-den Hall (the Great Buddha hall) of Todai-ji Temple in the same year.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After Jianzhen reached Satsuma (though some suggest it was Ryukyu) in December 753, he eventually made land in Naniwa no tsu (Naniwa Port in Osaka) in February 754.
sen.cmt: Word choice, punctuation, grammar. Repeated section removed.
sen.e: After Jianzhen reached Satsuma (though some suggest it was Ryukyu) in December 753, he eventually made land in Naniwa no tsu (Naniwa Port in Osaka) in February 754.

sen.j: 同年、東大寺大仏殿前で、聖武天皇、光明皇后、孝謙天皇らに菩薩戒を授けた。
sen.e: He taught Bosatsu-kai (Bodhisattva Precepts) for Emperor Shomu, Empress Komyo, Empress Koken, and so forth in front of Daibutsu-den Hall (the Great Buddha hall) of Todai-ji Temple in the same year.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He taught Bosatsu-kai (Bodhisattva Precepts) to Emperor Shomu, Empress Komyo, Empress Koken and others in front of Daibutsu-den Hall (the Great Buddha hall) at Todai-ji Temple in the same year.
He taught Bosatsu-kai (Bodhisattva Precepts) to Emperor Shomu, Empress Komyo, Empress Koken and others in front of Daibutsu-den Hall (the Great Buddha hall) at Todai-ji Temple in the same year.

sen.j: 日本で過ごした晩年の10年間のうち、前半5年間を東大寺で過ごした後、天平宝字3年（759年）、前述のように、今の唐招提寺の地を与えられた。
sen.e: After he spent 5 years--the first half of his 10-year late days in Japan--in Todaiji Temple, he was granted in 759 the site where the current Toshodai-ji Temple stood as mentioned above.
After he spent five years, the first half of his ten-year stay in Japan, at Todaiji Temple, he was granted the site where the current Toshodai-ji Temple stood in 759.
After he spent five years, the first half of his ten-year stay in Japan, at Todaiji Temple, he was granted the site where the current Toshodai-ji Temple stood in 759.

tit.e: Building and Maintenance of Buddhist temple
Building and Maintenance of the Buddhist temple
Building and Maintenance of the Buddhist temple

sen.j: 唐招提寺の寺地は平城京の右京五条二坊に位置した新田部親王邸跡地で、広さは4町であった。
sen.e: The site of Toshodai-ji Temple located at Nibou Gojo Ukyo in Heijokyo was where Imperial Prince Niitabe once lived and covered an area of 400 ares.
sen.cmt: 1町は約99.2 ares ということですので、約400ares と訳してあります。
sen.e: Toshodai-ji Temple, located at Nibou Gojo Ukyo in Heijokyo, was where Imperial Prince Niitabe once lived and covered an area of 400 acres.
Toshodai-ji Temple, located at Nibou Gojo Ukyo in Heijokyo, was where Imperial Prince Niitabe once lived and covered an area of 400 acres.

sen.j: 境内の発掘調査の結果、新田部親王邸と思われる前身建物跡が検出されている。
sen.e: As the result of excavations of the precinct, remains of the former building considered to have been the residence of Imperial Prince Niitabe was detected.
The remains of the former building considered to have been the residence of Imperial Prince Niitabe were detected as a result of excavations of the precinct.
The remains of the former building considered to have been the residence of Imperial Prince Niitabe were detected as a result of excavations of the precinct.

sen.j: また、境内から出土した古瓦のうち、単純な幾何学文の瓦（重圏文軒丸瓦と重弧文軒平瓦の組み合わせ）は、新田部親王邸のものと推定されている。
sen.e: In addition, among the old tiles unearthed in the precinct, tiles of simple geometry design (combination of hollow semicircular tiles of Jukenmon (concentric cricle design) and plain rectangular tiles of Jukomon) are assumed to have been used in the mansion of Imperial Prince Niitabe.
sen.cmt: 重弧文は、意味が調べられませんでした。
sen.e: In addition, among the old tiles unearthed from the precinct, tiles of simple geometric design (a combination of hollow semicircular tiles of Jukenmon (concentric circle design) and plain rectangular tiles of Jukomon) are assumed to have been used in the mansion of Imperial Prince Niitabe.

In addition, among the old tiles unearthed from the precinct, tiles of simple geometric design (a combination of hollow semicircular tiles of Jukenmon (concentric circle design) and plain rectangular tiles of Jukomon) are assumed to have been used in the mansion of Imperial Prince Niitabe.

sen.j: 寺内に現存する2棟の校倉造倉庫のうち、経蔵は新田部親王宅の倉庫を改造したものと思われる。
sen.e: The Kyozo (sutra repository), one of the two Azekura-zukuri style warehouses that still exist in the temple, is considered to be have been used as a warehouse in the mansion of Imperial Prince Niitabe and rebuilt.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The kyozo (sutra repository), one of the two azekura-zukuri style warehouses that still exist in the temple, is considered to be have been used as a warehouse in the mansion of Imperial Prince Niitabe, rebuilt at a later date.

The kyozo (sutra repository), one of the two azekura-zukuri style warehouses that still exist in the temple, is considered to be have been used as a warehouse in the mansion of Imperial Prince Niitabe, rebuilt at a later date.

sen.j: 他に新田部親王時代の建物はない。
sen.e: Any other building of the mansion of Imperial Prince Niitabe have not remained.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: No other buildings of the mansion of Imperial Prince Niitabe have remained.
No other buildings of the mansion of Imperial Prince Niitabe have remained.

sen.j: 『招提寺建立縁起』（『諸寺縁起集』所収）に、寺内の建物の名称とそれらの建物は誰の造営によるものであるかが記されている。
sen.e: "Shodaiji Konryu Engi" (The history of the Shodai-ji Temple) (included in "Shoji Engi Shu" (The book describing the history of every temple)) listed the names of the buildings of the temple and describes who had each of them built

"Shodaiji Konryu Engi" (The history of Shodai-ji Temple), included in "Shoji Engi Shu" (a book describing the history of every temple), lists the names of the buildings of the temple and describes who had each of them built.

"Shodaiji Konryu Engi" (The history of Shodai-ji Temple), included in "Shoji Engi Shu" (a book describing the history of every temple), lists the names of the buildings of the temple and describes who had each of them built.

sen.j: それによると、金堂は鑑真の弟子でともに来日した如宝（? - 815年）の造営、食堂（じきどう）は藤原仲麻呂家の施入（寄進）、羂索堂（けんさくどう）は藤原清河家の施入であった。
sen.e: It says that Nyoho (? - 815) who visited Japan with a disciple of Jianzhen had Kon-do Hall (main hall of a Buddhist temple) built, the FUJIWARA no Nakamaro family presented (donated) Jikido or a dining hall to the temple, and the FUJIWARA no Kiyokawa family presented (donated) Kensaku-do.

It says that Nyoho (date of birth unknown - 815), who visited Japan with a disciple of Jianzhen, had Kon-do Hall built, the FUJIWARA no Nakamaro family donated the Jikido dining hall to the temple, and the FUJIWARA no Kiyokawa family donated Kensaku-do.

It says that Nyoho (date of birth unknown - 815), who visited Japan with a disciple of Jianzhen, had Kon-do Hall built, the FUJIWARA no Nakamaro family donated the Jikido dining hall to the temple, and the FUJIWARA no Kiyokawa family donated Kensaku-do.

sen.j: また、講堂は、平城宮の東朝集殿を移築改造したものであった。
sen.e: It also says that Higashi Choshuden (government workers' building) was moved from Heijo-kyu Palace and reconstructed.
It also says that Higashi Choshuden (the government workers' building) was moved from Heijo-kyu Palace and rebuilt.
It also says that Higashi Choshuden (the government workers' building) was moved from Heijo-kyu Palace and rebuilt as Ko-do Hall.
sen.cmt: as Ko-do Hallを補足しました。

sen.j: 金堂は8世紀後半の宝亀年間（770 - 780年）の建築と推定される。
sen.e: It is estimated that the Kon-do Hall was built in the Hoki period (770 - 780).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is estimated that Kon-do Hall was built in the Hoki period (770 - 780).
It is estimated that Kon-do Hall was built in the Hoki period (770 - 780).

sen.j: この推定通りとすれば鑑真の没後に建立されたものである。
sen.e: If this estimate is accurate, it was built after the death of Jianzhen.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: If this estimate is accurate it was built after the death of Jianzhen.
If this estimate is accurate it was built after the death of Jianzhen.

sen.j: 伽藍の造営は鑑真の弟子の如宝、孫弟子の豊安（ぶあん）の代にまで引き継がれた。
sen.e: The building of Buddhist temple was taken over by the generation of a disciple of Jianzhen, Nyoho, and the subsequent generation of the grandson-disciple, Buan.
The building of the Buddhist temple was continued by the generation of Jianzhen and Nyoho's disciples, and the subsequent generation of the grandson-disciple, Buan.
The building of the Buddhist temple was continued by the generation of Jianzhen and Nyoho's disciples, and the subsequent generation of the grandson-disciple, Buan.

sen.j: 平安時代以後、一時衰退したが、鎌倉時代の僧・覚盛（かくじょう、1193年 - 1249年）によって復興された。
sen.e: It fell into a decline after the Heian Period but revived by Kakujo (1193 - 1249), a monk in the Kamakura Period.
It fell into decline after the Heian Period but was revived by Kakujo (1193 - 1249), a monk who lived in the Kamakura Period.
It fell into decline after the Heian Period but was revived by Kakujo (1193 - 1249), a monk who lived in the Kamakura Period.

sen.j: 唐招提寺金堂は現在解体修理中であり、2009年秋に落慶予定。
sen.e: The Toshodaiji Temple Kondo is under repairs involving prior dismantling, and the celebration of the reconstruction is scheduled in 2009.
The Toshodaiji Temple Kondo is under repair and has been dismantled, and a celebration of the reconstruction is scheduled for 2009.
The Toshodaiji Temple Kondo is under repair and has been dismantled, and a celebration of the reconstruction is scheduled for 2009.

sen.j: 以下の説明は修理前の状況を示す。
sen.e: The following describes what each of the buildings was before repair.
The following describes what each of the buildings was like before the repair:
The following describes what each of the buildings was like before the repair:

sen.j: 金堂（国宝）
sen.e: Kon-do Hall (National treasure)
Kon-do Hall (national treasure)
Kon-do Hall (national treasure)

sen.j: 奈良時代の金堂建築としては現存唯一のものである。
sen.e: It was the only one Kon-do Hall structure of the Nara period that exists today.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is the only Kon-do Hall structure from the Nara Period that exists today.
It is the only Kon-do Hall structure from the Nara Period that exists today.

sen.j: （奈良・新薬師寺の本堂は奈良時代の建築だが、元来本堂として建てられたものではない。）
sen.e: (Although the Hondo of Shinyakushi-ji Temple was a structure of the Nara Period, it was originally not designed for Hondo.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Although the Hondo of Shinyakushi-ji Temple is a structure from the Nara Period, it was originally not designed to be the Hondo.
(Although the Hondo of Shinyakushi-ji Temple is a structure from the Nara Period, it was originally not designed to be the Hondo.)
sen.cmt: カッコを補足しました。

sen.j: 寄棟造、単層で、屋根上左右に鴟尾（しび）が乗る。
sen.e: It is of a one-story Yosemune-zukuri (style of roof structure) and has a Shibi (ornamental ridge-end tile) each on the left and right sides of the roof.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It has a one-story yosemune-zukuri style roof and has a shibi (ornamental ridge-end tile) on both the left and right sides of the roof.
It has a one-story yosemune-zukuri style roof and has a shibi (ornamental ridge-end tile) on both the left and right sides of the roof.

sen.j: （西側の鴟尾が当初のもので、東側は鎌倉時代のもの。）
sen.e: The west side of the Shibi was placed from the start and the east side's was made in the Kamakura Period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The west side of the shibi is original but that on the east side was made in the Kamakura Period.
(The west side of the shibi is original but that on the east side was made in the Kamakura Period.)
sen.cmt: カッコを補足しました。

sen.j: 正面7間、側面4間（「間」は長さの単位ではなく、柱間の数を表わす）である。
sen.e: The front is 7-ken in width and the sides are 4-ken in length. ("ken" is not a unit of length but refers to a number of pillars).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The front is 7-ken in width and the sides are 4-ken in length ("ken" is not a unit of length but refers to the number of pillars).
The front is 7-ken in width and the sides are 4-ken in length ("ken" is not a unit of length but refers to the number of pillars).

sen.j: 手前の7間×1間を吹き放ち（壁、建具等を設けず、開放とする）にすることがこの建物の特色である。
sen.e: A feature of this structure is its 7-ken X 1-ken open-air space (without walls and door fittings) in the front.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: A feature of this structure is its 7-ken X 1-ken open-air space (without walls and door fittings) at the front.
A feature of this structure is its 7-ken X 1-ken open-air space (without walls and door fittings) at the front.

sen.j: 吹き放しとなった堂正面には8本の巨大な円柱が並び、この建物の見所となっている。
sen.e: Eight large round pillars the stand in a line in the front of the Hall are a point worthy of note in this structure.
Eight large round pillars that stand in a line at the front of the hall are a point worthy of note in this structure.
Eight large round pillars that stand in a line at the front of the hall are a point worthy of note in this structure.

sen.j: 建物は文永7年（1270年）と元禄6年 - 7年（1693年 - 1694年）に修理されており、屋根構造は近世風になっている。
sen.e: The structure was repaired in 1270 and from 1693 to 1694 and the roof is of early-modem style.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The structure was repaired in 1270 and from 1693 to 1694 and the roof is of early-modern style.
The structure was repaired in 1270 and from 1693 to 1694 and the roof is of early-modern style.

sen.j: （創建当時の屋根高は現状より2.8mほど低かった。）
sen.e: (The original building was 2.8m shorter than the current building in height to the roof.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The original building was 2.8m shorter in height than the current building, measured to the roof.
(The original building was 2.8m shorter in height than the current building, measured to the roof.)
sen.cmt: カッコを補足しました。

sen.j: 2005年、奈良県教育委員会の発表によれば、金堂の部材には西暦781年に伐採されたヒノキ材が使用されており、建造は同年以降ということになる。
sen.e: Nara Prefectural Board of Education announced in 2005 that the Kon-do Hall was of Japanese cypress cut in 781, suggesting that it was built in the same year or later.
Nara Prefectural Board of Education announced in 2005 that the Kon-do Hall was of Japanese cypress cut in 781, suggesting that it was built in the same year or later.
Nara Prefectural Board of Education announced in 2005 that the Kon-do Hall was of Japanese cypress cut in 781, suggesting that it was built in the same year or later.

sen.j: 堂内には中央に本尊・廬舎那仏坐像、向かって右に薬師如来立像、左に千手観音立像の3体の巨像を安置する。
sen.e: Three statues are enshrined in the Hall: a seated statue of Rushana Butsu stands in the center, a standing statue of Yakushi Nyorai to the right, and a standing statue of Thousand Armed Avalokiteshwara to the left.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Three statues are enshrined in the hall: a seated statue of Rushana Butsu stands in the center, a statue of Yakushi Nyorai to the right, and a statue of Thousand Armed Avalokiteshwara to the left.
Three statues are enshrined in the hall: a seated statue of Rushana Butsu stands in the center, a statue of Yakushi Nyorai to the right, and a statue of Thousand Armed Avalokiteshwara to the left.

sen.j: そのほか、本尊の手前左右に梵天・帝釈天立像、須弥壇の四隅に四天王立像を安置する。
sen.e: In addition, standing statues of Bonten and Taishakuten stand to the right and left of the front and standing statues of the Four Devas stand in the four corners.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In addition, statues of Bonten and Taishakuten stand to the right and left at the front and statues of the Four Devas stand in the four corners.
In addition, statues of Bonten and Taishakuten stand to the right and left at the front and statues of the Four Devas stand in the four corners of Syumidan.
sen.cmt: 「須弥壇の」の部分を補足しました。

sen.j: 講堂（国宝）
sen.e: Kodo Hall (Natural Treasure)
Kodo Hall (natural treasure)
Kodo Hall (natural treasure)

sen.j: 平城宮の東朝集殿を移築・改造したもの。
sen.e: It was originally Higashi Choshuden (government workers' building) moved from Heijo-kyu Palace and reconstructed.
It was originally the Higashi Choshuden (government workers' building) moved from Heijo-kyu Palace and rebuilt.
It was originally the Higashi Choshuden (government workers' building) moved from Heijo-kyu Palace and rebuilt.

sen.j: 東朝集殿は、壁や建具のほとんどない開放的な建物である。
sen.e: Higashi Choshuden has a structure of an open room with few walls and door fittings.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Higashi Choshuden has an open structure with few walls and door fittings.
Higashi Choshuden has an open structure with few walls and door fittings.

sen.j: 屋根は切妻造であったが、寺院用に改造するにあたって、屋根を入母屋造とし、建具を入れている。
sen.e: Its roof was originally of a kirizuma-zukuri style (an architectural style with a gabled roof) but was reconstructed into an irimoya style (building with a half-hipped roof) with door fittings.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Its roof was originally of kirizuma-zukuri style (an architectural style with a gabled roof) but was rebuilt in irimoya style (with a half-hipped roof) with door fittings.
Its roof was originally of kirizuma-zukuri style (an architectural style with a gabled roof) but was rebuilt in irimoya style (with a half-hipped roof) with door fittings.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代の建治元年（1275年）にも改造されているが、天平時代宮廷建築の唯一の遺構として極めて貴重である。
sen.e: It is quite precious as only one ancient structural remnant of court architect in the Tenpyo era, although it was also reconstructed in 1275 in the Kamakura Period.
It is viewed as precious as it is the only ancient structural remnant of court architecture of the Tenpyo era, although it was rebuilt in 1275 in the Kamakura Period.
It is viewed as precious as it is the only ancient structural remnant of court architecture of the Tenpyo era, although it was rebuilt in 1275 in the Kamakura Period.

sen.j: 堂内には本尊弥勒如来坐像（重文、鎌倉時代）と、持国天、増長天立像（重文、奈良時代）を安置する。
sen.e: Enshrined in the Hall are the principal seated statue of Miroku-nyorai (Important Cultural Property of the Kamakura Period) and a standing statue of Dhrtarastra and Virudhaka (Important Cultural Property of the Nara Period),

Enshrined in the hall are the principal statues of Miroku-nyorai (an Important Cultural Property of the Kamakura Period) and Dhrtarastra and Virudhaka (an Important Cultural Property of the Nara Period).

Enshrined in the hall are the principal statues of Miroku-nyorai (an Important Cultural Property of the Kamakura Period) and Dhrtarastra and Virudhaka (an Important Cultural Property of the Nara Period).

sen.j: 1970年に新宝蔵が完成するまでは、堂内に多数の仏像を安置していた。
sen.e: Many statues had been enshrined in the Hall by the time the new hozo (treasure house) was completed in 1970.
Many statues had been enshrined in the hall by the time the new hozo (treasure house) was completed in 1970.
Many statues had been enshrined in the hall by the time the new hozo (treasure house) was completed in 1970.

sen.j: その他の建造物
sen.e: Other structures
Other structures
Other structures

sen.j: 経蔵、宝蔵（各国宝） - 境内東側に並んで建つ。
sen.e: Kyozo and hozo (both national treasures) - structures that stand in line in the east side of the precinct.
Kyozo and hozo (both national treasures), structures that stand in a line at the east side of the precinct.
Kyozo and hozo (both national treasures), structures that stand in a line at the east side of the precinct.

sen.j: ともに奈良時代の校倉造倉庫。
sen.e: Both of them are warehouses of Azekura-zukuri style in the Nara period.
Both are warehouses in the azekura-zukuri style, built in the Nara Period.
Both are warehouses in the azekura-zukuri style, built in the Nara Period.

sen.j: 経蔵は唐招提寺創建以前ここにあった新田部親王邸の倉を改造したものとされる。
sen.e: The Kyozo is considered to have been reconstructed from a warehouse in the mansion of Imperial Prince Niitabe, which had been there before Toshodai-ji Temple was founded and reconstructed, while hozo is estimated to have been built after the temple was founded there.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The kyozo is considered to have been built out of a warehouse belonging to the mansion of Imperial Prince Niitabe, and was built before Toshodai-ji Temple was founded.
sen.cmt: Grammar, changed for clarity. Duplicated section removed.
sen.e: The kyozo is considered to have been built out of a warehouse belonging to the mansion of Imperial Prince Niitabe, and was built before Toshodai-ji Temple was founded.

sen.j: 一方、宝蔵はここが寺になってから建てられたものと推定される。
sen.e: The hozo, on the other hand, is estimated to have been built after the temple was founded there.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The hozo, on the other hand, is estimated to have been built after the temple was founded.
The hozo, on the other hand, is estimated to have been built after the temple was founded.

sen.j: 鼓楼（国宝） - 金堂・講堂の東側に建つ、小規模な2階建の建物。
sen.e: Koro Tower (National treasure) - a small two-story structure that stands to the east of the Kon-do Hall and the Kodo Hall.
Koro Tower (national treasure), a small two-story structure that stands to the east of the Kon-do Hall and the Kodo Hall.
Koro Tower (national treasure), a small two-story structure that stands to the east of the Kon-do Hall and the Kodo Hall.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代・仁治元年（1240年）の建築。
sen.e: It was a structure built in 1249 in the Kamakura Period.
It was built in 1249 in the Kamakura Period.
It was built in 1240 in the Kamakura Period.

sen.j: 鑑真請来の仏舎利を安置するため、舎利殿ともいう。
sen.e: It is also called Shariden hall (relic hall/hall for a bone of the Buddha), because Buddha's ashes brought by Jianzhen is enshrined.
It is also known as Shariden Hall (a hall which houses a relic or bone of the Buddha), because it contains the ashes of Buddha brought by Jianzhen.
It is also known as Shariden Hall (a hall which houses a relic or bone of the Buddha), because it contains the ashes of Buddha brought by Jianzhen.

sen.j: 礼堂（重文） - 鼓楼の東にある南北に細長い建物。
sen.e: Rai-do hall (a worship hall)- a north-south elongated structure that stands east of Koro Tower
Rai-do Hall (a worship hall), an elongated structure running from north to south that stands to the east of Koro Tower.
Rai-do Hall (a worship hall), an elongated structure running from north to south that stands to the east of Koro Tower.

sen.j: もとの僧房を弘安6年（1283年）に改築したものである。
sen.e: It was originally priests' living quarters and reconstructed in 1283
It was originally used for priests' living quarters and rebuilt in 1283.
It was originally used for priests' living quarters and rebuilt in 1283.

sen.j: 隣の鼓楼（舎利殿）に安置された仏舎利を礼拝するための堂である。
sen.e: It is a structure in which people pray before Buddha's ashes enshrined in Koro Tower (Shariden hall).
It is a structure in which people pray before the ashes of Buddha enshrined in Koro Tower (Shariden Hall).
It is a structure in which people pray before the ashes of Buddha enshrined in Koro Tower (Shariden Hall).

sen.j: 内部に清凉寺式釈迦如来立像（重文・秘仏）を安置する。
sen.e: Seiryojishiki Shakyanyorai-zo (Seiryo-ji Temple-style statue of Shakyanyorai) (important cultural property, a hidden Buddhist statue) are enshrined in the building.
The Seiryojishiki Shakyanyorai-zo (Seiryo-ji Temple-style statue of Shakyanyorai, an important cultural property and hidden Buddhist statue) is enshrined in the building.
sen.cmt: Grammar, punctuation. The term 'hidden Buddhist statue' would benefit from a little more explanation perhaps.
sen.e: The Seiryojishiki Shakyanyorai-zo (Seiryo-ji Temple-style statue of Shakyanyorai, an important cultural property and hidden Buddhist statue) is enshrined in the building.

sen.j: 戒壇 - 境内西側にある。
sen.e: Kaidan (Buddhist ordination platform) - standing in the west side of the precinct
Kaidan (Buddhist ordination platform), stood at the west side of the precinct.
Kaidan (Buddhist ordination platform), stood at the west side of the precinct.

sen.j: 戒壇は、出家者が正式の僧となるための受戒の儀式を行う場所。
sen.e: It is a place where a ceremony to receive the religious precept was held for a renunciant monk to become a proper monk.
This is the place where the ceremony to receive the religious precepts was held for renunciant monks to enable them to become proper monks.
This is the place where the ceremony to receive the religious precepts was held for renunciant monks to enable them to become proper monks.

sen.j: 戒壇院の建物は江戸時代末期の嘉永元4（1851年）に焼失して以来再建されていない。
sen.e: The structure of Kaidan-in has not been reconstructed after it was burnt down in a fire in 1851 in the end of Edo Period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The Kaidan-in was not rebuilt after being burnt down in a fire in 1851, at the end of the Edo Period.
The Kaidan-in was not rebuilt after being burnt down in a fire in 1851, at the end of the Edo Period.

sen.j: 3段の石壇のみが残っている。
sen.e: Only three stone steps remain.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Only three stone steps remain.
Only three stone steps remain.

sen.j: 1980年にインド・サンチーの古塔を模した宝塔が壇上に置かれた。
sen.e: A hoto that imitates an old Sanchi Stupa in India was placed on the altar in 1980.
A hoto designed to resemble the former Sanchi Stupa in India was placed on the altar in 1980.
A hoto designed to resemble the former Sanchi Stupa in India was placed on the altar in 1980.

sen.j: 唐招提寺の戒壇は創建時からあったものとする説と、鎌倉時代の弘安7年（1284年）に初めて造られたとする説とがある。
sen.e: Some suggest that the Kaidan of Toshodai-ji Temple has been there since its foundation, while other suggest that it was built in 1284 in the Kamakura Period for the first time.
Some suggest that the Kaidan of Toshodai-ji Temple has been there since the temple's foundation, while others claim that it was originally built in 1284.
Some suggest that the Kaidan of Toshodai-ji Temple has been there since the temple's foundation, while others claim that it was originally built in 1284.

sen.j: 御影堂（重文） - 鑑真の肖像彫刻（国宝）を安置する（開山忌の6月5日－7日のみ公開）。
sen.e: Goei-do Hall (hall dedicated to the sect's founder) (important cultural property) -The image sculpture of Jianzhen (national treasure) is enshrined (and made public from 5th through 7th of June on the Kaizan-ki (anniversary of the temple-founder's death))

Goei-do Hall (the hall dedicated to the founder of the sect), an important cultural property, enshrines a sculpture of Jianzhen (a national treasure), and is made public from 5th through 7th of June on the Kaizan-ki (anniversary of the temple-founder's death).

Goei-do Hall (the hall dedicated to the founder of the sect), an important cultural property, enshrines a sculpture of Jianzhen (a national treasure), and is made public from 5th through 7th of June on the Kaizan-ki (anniversary of the temple-founder's death).

sen.j: 建物は興福寺の有力な子院であった一乗院（廃絶）の遺構。
sen.e: The structure is an ancient structural remnant of (extinct) Ichijo-in Temple, a noted branch temple of Kofuku-ji Temple.
The building is an ancient structural remnant of Ichijo-in Temple, now destroyed, a noted branch temple of Kofuku-ji Temple.
The building is an ancient structural remnant of Ichijo-in Temple, now destroyed, a noted branch temple of Kofuku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 1962年までは地方裁判所の庁舎として使用され、1964年に唐招提寺に移築された。
sen.e: It had been used as an office building of the District Court until 1962 and moved to Toshodai-ji Temple in 1964.
It was used as an office building of the District Court until 1962 and moved to Toshodai-ji Temple in 1964.
It was used as an office building of the District Court until 1962 and moved to Toshodai-ji Temple in 1964.

sen.j: 障壁画「黄山暁雲」は鑑真の御霊を慰める為、日本画家東山魁夷によって新たに描かれたものである。
sen.e: "Huangshan Mountains in Morning Mist," is a wall painting, drawn by Kaii HIGASHIYAMA, a Japanese-style painter, for the memory of Jianzhen.
"Huangshan Mountains in Morning Mist", a wall painting drawn by the Japanese-style painter Kaii HIGASHIYAMA, was painted in memory of Jianzhen.
"Huangshan Mountains in Morning Mist," a wall painting drawn by the Japanese-style painter Kaii HIGASHIYAMA, was painted in memory of Jianzhen.
sen.cmt: カンマの位置を修正しました。

sen.j: 新宝蔵 - 1970年に完成した鉄筋コンクリートの収蔵庫。
sen.e: New hozo- a repository of reinforced concrete completed in 1970
New hozo, a storage room of reinforced concrete, completed in 1970
New hozo, a storage room of reinforced concrete, completed in 1970

sen.j: 例年春と秋に期日を限って公開される。
sen.e: It was made public only for a limited period in spring and fall every year.
It is only open to the public for a limited period in spring and fall every year.
It is only open to the public for a limited period in spring and fall every year.

sen.j: 金堂にあった木造大日如来坐像（重文）のほか、「旧講堂木彫仏群」といわれる、もと講堂に仮安置されていた奈良時代末期～平安時代前期の一木彫仏像群が収蔵され、一部が展示されている。
sen.e: Stored or partially exhibited are a group of statues caved of Ichiboku (one tree) named "a group of wooden Buddha in the former Kodo Hall" made from the late Nara period to the early Heian period and once temporarily placed in Kodo Hall, in addition to a wooden statue of the seated Dainichi Nyorai (an important cultural property) once placed in Kon-do Hall

A group of statues carved from ichiboku (one tree) called "a group of wooden Buddhas of the former Kodo Hall" created between the late Nara and early Heian periods and once temporarily placed in Kodo Hall, and a wooden statue of the seated Dainichi Nyorai (an important cultural property) once placed in Kon-do Hall are both stored and occasionally exhibited here.

A group of statues carved from ichiboku (one tree) called "a group of wooden Buddhas of the former Kodo Hall" created between the late Nara and early Heian periods and once temporarily placed in Kodo Hall, and a wooden statue of the seated Dainichi Nyorai (an important cultural property) once placed in Kon-do Hall are both stored and some of them are exhibited here.
sen.cmt: 「一部が展示されている」を変えました。

sen.j: 東塔跡 - かつて存在した五重塔の跡。
sen.e: The site of East pagoda--where a 5-story pagoda once stood.
The site of the East Pagoda, where a five-story pagoda once stood.
The site of the East Pagoda, where a five-story pagoda once stood.

sen.j: 『日本紀略』によれば、弘仁元（810年）の創建。
sen.e: "Summary of Japanese Chronologies" ("Nihongi Ryaku") says that it was built in 810.
The "Summary of Japanese Chronologies" ("Nihongi Ryaku") states that it was built in 810.
The "Summary of Japanese Chronologies" ("Nihongi Ryaku") states that it was built in 810.

sen.j: 享和2年（1802年）落雷で焼失した。
sen.e: Lightning hit and burned it down in 1802.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Lightning hit and burned it down in 1802.
Lightning hit and burned it down in 1802.

sen.j: （西塔については、あったとする史料もあるが定かではない。）
sen.e: (Some historical materials suggest that a western pagoda once stood but this is not clear.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Some historical sources suggest that a western pagoda once stood here but this is not clear.
(Some historical sources suggest that a western pagoda once stood here but this is not clear.)
sen.cmt: カッコを補足しました。

sen.j: 境内が国の史跡に指定されている。
sen.e: The precinct is designated as a historic site.
The precinct is designated as a historic site.
The precinct is designated as a historic site.

sen.j: 梵網会（うちわまき）（5月19日） - 鎌倉時代に唐招提寺を復興した覚盛上人を偲んで行われる行事。
sen.e: Bonmoe (the gathering to read Bonmo-sutra and pray happiness) (May 18) - an event to remember Kakujo Shonin that revived Toshodai-ji Temple during the Kamakura Period
Bonmoe (a gathering held to read the Bonmo-sutra and pray for happiness), on May 18, is an event to remember the Kakujo Shonin who restored Toshodai-ji Temple in the Kamakura Period
Bonmoe (Uchiwamaki) (a gathering held to read the Bonmo-sutra and pray for happiness), on May 19, is an event to remember the Kakujo Shonin who restored Toshodai-ji Temple in the Kamakura Period
sen.cmt: May 18→19、うちわまきを補足しました。

sen.j: 覚盛は殺生戒を守り、蚊も殺さなかったといわれる。
sen.e: Kakujo is said to have abided by Sessho-kai (the Buddhist precept of the prohibition of killing living things indiscriminately).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Kakujo is said to have abided by the sessho-kai (the Buddhist precept of the prohibition of killing living things indiscriminately).
Kakujo is said to have abided by the sessho-kai (the Buddhist precept of the prohibition of killing living things indiscriminately) so strictly that he did not kill even a mosquito.
sen.cmt: 「蚊も殺さなかった」を補足しました。

sen.j: その徳を偲んだ法華寺の尼僧がせめてうちわで蚊を払えるようにと霊前にうちわを供えたのが始まりといわれる。
sen.e: The event is said to have started when a nun (a Buddhist nun) of Hokke-ji Temple remembered his virtues by offering a round fan on the altar that might have at least allowed him to flap at mosquitoes,
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The event is said to have started when the Buddhist monk from Hokke-ji Temple remembered his virtues by placing a round fan on the altar so that he could swat away mosquitoes.
The event is said to have started when the Buddhist nun from Hokke-ji Temple remembered his virtues by placing a round fan on the altar so that he could swat away mosquitoes.

sen.j: 15時、ハート型をした3,000枚のうちわが鼓楼より参拝者に向けばら撒かれる。
sen.e: At 15 o'clock, 3000 heart-shaped fans are scattered from Koro Tower to visitors.
At 3pm, from Koro Tower three-thousand heart-shaped fans are scattered and thrown to visitors.
At 3pm, from Koro Tower three-thousand heart-shaped fans are scattered and thrown to visitors.

sen.j: このうちわは拾えた参拝者から縁起物として非常に貴重がられている。
sen.e: This fan is regarded by visitors who can catch it. as valuable as an object that will bring good fortune.
These fans are regarded by those visitors who can catch one as a valuable object that will bring good fortune.
These fans are regarded by those visitors who can catch one as a valuable object that will bring good fortune.

sen.j: 害虫よけや、雷よけなどのご利益があるとされる。
sen.e: It is also regarded as having a divine favor in protecting harmful insects and lightening.
It is also regarded as having divine favor in protecting the holder from harmful insects and lightening.
It is also regarded as having divine favor in protecting the holder from harmful insects and lightening.

sen.j: 撒かれるうちわは寺の手づくりである。
sen.e: The scattered fans are hand-made in the temple.
The fans are hand-made in the temple.
The fans are hand-made in the temple.

sen.j: 開山忌（6月5日 - 6月7日） - 6月6日が鑑真の命日にあたり、その前後3日間、御影堂において国宝の鑑真和上像を開扉する。
sen.e: Kaizan-ki (anniversary of the temple-founder's death) (June 5 to 7) - As the anniversary of Jianzhen's death falls on June 6, the statue of Jianzhen of a national treasure is made open at Goei-do Hall (hall dedicated to the sect's founder) for 3 days before and after the anniversary.

Kaizan-ki (the anniversary of the founder of the temple's death), from June 5 to 7; as the anniversary of Jianzhen's death falls on June 6 the statue of Jianzhen (national treasure) is available to view at Goei-do Hall (the hall dedicated to the sect's founder) for three days before and after the anniversary.

Kaizan-ki (the anniversary of the founder of the temple's death), from June 5 to 7; as the anniversary of Jianzhen's death falls on June 6 the statue of Jianzhen (national treasure) is available to view at Goei-do Hall (the hall dedicated to the sect's founder) for three days before and after the anniversary.

sen.j: 同時に東山魁夷画伯の障壁画も公開される。
sen.e: The wall painting by the painter Kaii HIGASHIYAMA is made open at the same time.
The wall painting by the painter Kaii HIGASHIYAMA is also on display during the three-day period.
The wall painting by the painter Kaii HIGASHIYAMA is also on display during the three-day period.

sen.j: 観月讃仏会（かんげつさんぶつえ、旧暦8月14日 - 16日） - 夜間に金堂を開扉し、堂内の三尊仏がシルエットとして浮かび上がる。
sen.e: Kangetsu Sanbutsu E (The gathering to see the moon and praise Buddha) (14 to 16 August according to the lunar calendar) - The Kon-do Hall is made opened during the night so the silhouettes of Sansonbutsu (three Buddhist deities) stand out sharply with the light.

Kangetsu Sanbutsu E (a gathering held to watch the moon and praise Buddha), 14 to 16 August depending on the lunar calendar; the Kon-do Hall is open to the public during the night and the silhouettes of the Sansonbutsu (three Buddhist deities) stand out sharply against the light.

Kangetsu Sanbutsu E (a gathering held to watch the moon and praise Buddha), 14 to 16 August depending on the lunar calendar; the Kon-do Hall is open to the public during the night and the silhouettes of the Sansonbutsu (three Buddhist deities) stand out sharply against the light.

sen.j: 近畿日本鉄道近鉄橿原線西ノ京駅下車徒歩8分
sen.e: A 8-minute walk from Nishinokyo Station of Kintetsu Kashihara Line, Kinki Nippon Railway Company
An eight-minute walk from Nishinokyo Station on the Kintetsu Kashihara Line, run by Kinki Nippon Railway Company
An eight-minute walk from Nishinokyo Station on the Kintetsu Kashihara Line, run by Kinki Nippon Railway Company
